Group Visit to "Yasukuni Shrine" in Japan under Fire 
    Pyongyang, October 26 (KCNA) -- The Japanese chief executive and a group of right-wing conservative politicians visited the "Yasukuni Shrine". Rodong Sinmun Wednesday says in a signed commentary carried in this connection: This was an open challenge to the world public hoping Japan would settle its past crimes and turn over a new leaf this year marking the 60th anniversary of its defeat and an insult to the Asian people opposed to the revival of militarism in Japan.
  The fact that lending a deaf ear to the voices of the world people of conscience, the prime minister of Japan visited again the shrine which "honors" the top class war criminals who earned ill fame for waging a war to conquer Asia in the past is a very serious development. While giving lip-service to "apology" and "reflection" on the crimes committed by Japan against the people of Korea and other peace-loving people of Asia and the rest of the world, he paid a surprise visit to the shrine again. This was an act of fooling and mocking at the world public opinion and human conscience. This was prompted by a sinister intention of the Japanese authorities to stir up militarism in the Japanese society and beautify and repeat the criminal history of aggression. 
 The Japanese prime minister's  recent visit to the shrine brought to light the true colors of the untrustworthy chief executive as his words do not agree with his deeds and put Japan into a more deplorable situation where it is standing further isolated and rebuffed by the Asian countries. 
 Should the Japanese ruling quarters persist in such reckless behavior as visiting the shrine defying the mind-set of the public at home and abroad, this will only increase Japan's international isolation.

articles.title: Kim Yong Nam Receives Credentials from Slovak Ambassador
Memorial Concert Opens
articles.content:
Kim Yong Nam Receives Credentials from Slovak Ambassador
    Pyongyang, October 26 (KCNA) -- Kim Yong Nam, president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, received credentials from Zigmund Bertok, Slovak ambassador e. p. to the DPRK, at the Mansudae Assembly Hall Wednesday. 
 On hand were Kim Hyong Jun, vice-minister of Foreign Affairs, and a staff member of the Slovak embassy.    
 The president had a talk with the ambassador after receiving credentials.

articles.title: Wreaths to Nigerian Embassy
Greetings to Prime Minister of Saint Vincent and Grenadines
articles.content:
Wreaths to Nigerian Embassy
    Pyongyang, October 26 (KCNA) -- The DPRK Ministry of Foreign Affairs, the Ministry of Foreign Trade, the Bureau of Diplomatic Corps Affairs and the DPRK-Nigeria Friendship Association sent wreaths to the Nigerian embassy here on Wednesday to express condolences over the death of Stella Obasanjo, wife of Olusegun Obasanjo, president and commander-in-chief of the armed forces of Nigeria. 
 Wreaths were laid before a photo of the late.    
  Yang Hyong Sop, vice-president of the Presidium of the DPRK Supreme People's Assembly, Mun Jae Chol, acting chairman of the Korean Committee for Cultural Relations with Foreign Countries, Kim Hyong Jun, vice-minister of Foreign Affairs, and officials concerned visited the embassy and observed a moment's silence in memory of the late, and made entries in the mourners' book.

articles.content:
Greetings to Prime Minister of Saint Vincent and Grenadines
    Pyongyang, October 26 (KCNA) -- Pak Pong Ju, premier of the DPRK Cabinet, sent a message of greetings to Ralph Gonsalves, prime minister of Saint Vincent and Grenadines, on the occasion of the 26th anniversary of the independence of the country. 
 Expressing the belief that the friendly relations between the two countries would continue to develop, the message wished him and the government of Saint Vincent and Grenadines greater successes in the work for prosperity of the country.
